item.description:
There is something for everyone at Leeds City Art Gallery. You will find traditional prints, watercolours, paintings and sculptures as well as contemporary works made with plastic grapes and twintubs.

At Leeds City Art Gallery you can find some of the most outstanding works of British Art outside of London.

Here visitors can experience a technological adventure travelling from the days when waterwheels powered an entire factory to the coming of steam and diesel power.  From spinning wheels in the Weaver's cottage to working steam locomotives Armley shows how industry has changed everyone's lives.

Here you can wander through the streets, shops and workplaces of a Victorian city and experience life in the 19th century.  Abbey House was once the gate house of the 12th century Kirkstall Abbey.  Today you can find out how monks lived, worked and worshipped and then wander round Here you can wander through the streets, shops and workplaces of a Victorian city and experience life in the 19th century.  Abbey House was once the gate house of the 12th century Kirkstall Abbey.  Today you can find out how monks lived, worked and worshipped and then wander round the ruins.

Family friendly activities and events take place on a regular basis.

Admission Adults £3.50, concessions £2.50 accompanied children £1.50.  Family ticket 2 adults and up to 3 children £5the ruins.

One of the best preserved Abbeys in the country.

Enjoy a visit to Kirkstall Abbey, one of the most complete examples of a medieval Cistercian abbey in Britain.

Set in wonderful parkland along the banks of the River Aire, Kirkstall Abbey boasts historic architecture amid a haven of wildlife and greenery.

Built on an artificial island between the River Aire and the Aire & Calder Navigation Thwaite Mills Watermill is a beautiful building.

No one would suspect that during its working life the mill produced putty, prison bread and oil for Stephenson's Rocket.  A guide in Victorian work clothes leads visitors through the bowels of the enormous building which drew all of its power from two gigantic water wheels.  The restored Manager's House shows how many ordinary Victorians lived and worked.

Explore three floors of this magnificent country house, admire beautiful paintings, furniture and silver.  Free audio guides takes you on a special tours around the house.  Then stroll down to the largest rare breeds centre in the world at Home Farm.  Here you can see rare sheep pigs, cattle and poultry.  Examine historic agricultural equipment such as horse-drawn carts, wagons and threshing machines.  Wander around 1500 acres of parkland, woodland, farmland and gardens.

Home Farm is a large working farm and is the largest Rare Breeds Centre in Europe. 

Home to more than 400 animals including rare and traditional sheep, pigs, poultry and cattle.  There is a Georgian dovecote containing nesting holes for 2000 pairs of pigeons, a working estate joiner's shop and sawmills.

In the restored workshops you can take part in traditional craft demonstrations such as butter and cheese-making, blacksmithing and much more.  There are even "hands-on" opportunities with some of the animals.

In the Stable Courtyard there is a tearoom and a shop.

Regular timetable of family-friendly activities and events throughout the year in the House, Park and Farm.

Last admission to the house is 45 minutes before closing.

The family that lived at the Hall where called the Gascoignes.  Peek into bedrooms, relax in the drawing room and imagine a fifteen course feast in the dining room.  The Gascogines were great collectors and the House contains a wonderful range of furniture, paintings, sculpture, silver, pottery and porcelain.

Outside follow in the footsteps of Mrs Gwendolen Gascoigne who designed the beautiful gardens.  Red deer and rare breeds of cattle can be seen on walks through the parkland.

There is also an exotic Bird Garden home to 200 species from around the world.

Many family-friendly activities take place in the House and Gardens ranging from tepee games with the Rangers to tea-parties in the House. Ring for admission costs.

Lots to do at Pudsey Park from the animals in the Aviary and Aquarium to Skateboarding and mini football.  Have a leisurely stroll around the tree lined parkland.  Visit the parrots, finches and exotic fish within the aviaries adn aquaria.

 

 

How to get there by bus.

Click on the bus numbers below for timetable details.

 

4, 8, 9, 44, 66, 81A, 88, 91A, 205, 711, X11

Experience the humidity of the swamp and rainforest and walk among tumbling waterfalls and alongside swirling pools of colourful fish, tropical plants and flowers.  Discover a world of reptiles, spiders, amphibians, birds, small mammals and butterflies. There are piranhas and other exotic fish in the depths of the aquarium.
 

On Wednesdays during Leeds school holidays 'Meet the Keeper' and some of the more unusual residents at Tropical World.


Open every day 10am until 6pm throughout the Summer and 10am until 4pm throughout the Winter. Last admissions are 30mins before closing time. 


Tropical World is Closed Christmas Day, Boxing Day and New Years Day. 


Admission


Adults £3.25, children (5-15) £2 and under 5s free.

Surrounded by some of the city's most important buildings, including the Town Hall, Civic Hall, Leeds General Infirmary and the Civic Theatre, Millennium Square is the new heart for Leeds city centre. The site includes areas for staged performances such as outdoor theatre, pop concerts, operatic and orchestral performances, as well as civic ceremonies, fairs, markets and street entertainment.

Situated in the Electric Press building, at the heart of Millennium Square, the theatre showcases the best national and international touring productions, and has quickly established itself as a key destination for audiences looking for an entertaining, inspiring and adventurous night out.

At the same time Carriageworks Theatre gives extensive support to artists in the north to help them grow and develop their work.

countrysiderangers@leeds.gov.uk.  The Chevin is well served with footpaths and bridleways.  All of the routes are steep and can be muddy in wet conditions.  The best outlook is the Surprise View which can be reached easily by walking up from the Becon House Car Park.  Don't go on a foggy day though!

If you're mad about wildlife then the Chevin Wildlife WATCH group is perfect for you.  This group meets twice a week and has a varied programme - walks, tree recognition sessions, bird walks, mini-beast hunting, den building, day trips and barbecues.

The sessions start at 10am and finish at 12 noon unless otherwise stated.  The cost to join is a Â£1 per child unless the group is out on a site trip.

To stay on your own you have to be 8 yrs plus and your parent or carer will have to sign a consent form.  If under 8 a parent or guardian has to stay with you.

The Chevin can get quite cold so make sure you wear suitable clothing and strong boots.

To get more information about what the group is doing contact the Parks & Countryside Ranger Service on 0113 237 5268 or email countrysiderangers@leeds.gov.uk. 

 

How to get there by bus.

Click on the bus numbers below for timetable details.

How to get there by bus.

Click the bus numbers below for timetable details.

 

5, 64, 68, 68A
Thackray Medical Museum tells the story of medicine, explaining how advances in medicine have changed our lives, transporting visitors into a living experience of health, past, present and future.

item.place_title: The Venue, Leeds College of Music

item.description:
Leeds Museum Discovery Centre is a unique museum resource. Housing and caring for Leeds' fantastic collections, the Discovery Centre is a state-of-the-art storage facility.  All are welcome to visit the Discovery Centre for research or to see its unique resources.

Tours usually last for 45 minutes, other booked visits may take up to 4 hours. Please telephone to visit the Discovery Centre or book onto one of our events.

Please call the Discovery Centre to arrange an appointment.
Mulitplex Cinema

Leeds' only surviving picture palace.

Where certification allows, under 14s tickets are £4.00 for stalls and balcony. For Breeze card holders over the age of 14, we provide a £1 discount from the normal stalls ticket price of £5.50. Check out our Saturday matinee screenings for bargain price tickets!

Leeds-based Yorkshire Dance champions the development of dance in Yorkshire. It does so by raising standards, increasing knowledge and understanding and fostering creativity and innovation.

It creates opportunities for people of all ages, backgrounds and abilities to see, make and take part in high quality dance that is rooted in their creativity, in their lives and in their communities, with the power to transform and inspire.

It creates opportunities for emerging and established artists and practitioners to research, create and present new contemporary work on the small scale, and in communities, developing their skills, expertise and networks.

It creates opportunities for people to experience dance by working with partners, local authorities and the arts, in health and in sport, building a region-wide infrastructure for dance development.

item.place_title: Armley One Stop Centre, Town Street.

item.description:
In the Museum you can come face to face with Leeds tiger if you dare, step into 'Ancient Worlds' and meet Nesyamun, the Leeds mummy, or dig for fossils in the 'Life on Earth' gallery. 

Make sure you don't miss Eating Creepy Crawlies- gruesome fun for those who dare to brave locusts for lunch! This is the Museum's first temporary exhibition (admission applies) which comes to Leeds from the Natural History Museum.

The Museum has a large book and gift shop and cafe where you can relax.

The Henry Moore Institute is an award-winning exhibitions venue, research centre and sculpture archive. It is situated in the heart of the city next to Leeds Art Gallery, and is connected to it by a walkway so that visitors can move freely between the two venues.

The Institute is open year round, free of charge and showcases the best in international sculpture, both historical and contemporary. It also runs a world-class programme of research and events, and is home to the country's leading sculpture archive.

The Henry Moore Institute is part of The Henry Moore Foundation, established by sculptor Henry Moore in 1977.

item.place_title: Leeds Met Gallery and Studio Theatre
item.description:
The Gallery remains dedicated to the development and presentation of contemporary visual art reflecting new practice, new ideas and excellence in execution.

Through a programme of work that challenges perceptions and provokes debate about the changing position of contemporary art within the cultural arena, we aim to provide a focus for critical understanding and appreciation of contemporary practice. We are committed to support the development of new work from artists in the early stages of their careers. The Gallery welcomes proposals from artists for solo, group or thematic exhibitions.

The Stanley & Audrey Burton Gallery (formerly the University Gallery) offers both a programme of temporary exhibitions in its Special Exhibitions Room and a display of selected items from the University Art Collection in its main gallery.
The Education Room houses the University’s collection of drawings and other works on paper; the Education Room also offers designated space for private study, research and teaching, relating to both the collections and the exhibition programme.

Accumulated over more than a hundred years, the Collection consists mainly of European, principally British paintings, drawings and prints, dating from the 17th century up to the present day, with small collections of sculpture, ceramics, and photographs. Outstanding elements are the Sadler Gift of early 20th-century British art, the collections of drawings and paintings by artists of the Camden Town and Bloomsbury groups and their contemporaries, and works by former Gregory Fellows in Painting and Sculpture.

Harewood is the Home of the Earl and Countess of Harewood and sits at the heart of Yorkshire in the setting of Yorkshire’s most beautiful landscape.

One of the treasure houses of England, Harewood was built in the mid-18th century and has magnificent interiors by Robert Adam, furniture by Thomas Chippendale and paintings by JMW Turner, Reynolds, Titian and El Greco, among others. The collections of paintings, furniture and porcelain are as fine as any in the land and you’ll gain a fascinating insight into the servants’ domain Below Stairs in the House.

An Italianate Terrace, designed by Charles Barry, stretches along the South Front of the House and provides stunning views of ‘Capability’ Brown's landscape and lake.

But that’s not all. Harewood is just as much about today as it is about history. There are exhibitions of contemporary art, an award-winning educational department, renowned Bird Garden and over 100 acres of exquisite gardens; including a plant-hunters paradise in the Himalayan garden, working kitchen garden and parterre terrace with herbaceous and tropical borders.

Expect the unexpected at Harewood with special events and themed weekends throughout the season to surprise you; from children’s activities to car rallies, kite festivals to dog shows, our much-loved VW Festival, and don’t miss our annual Medieval Faire!

Whether you want to visit the House and its wonderful collections, relax in the Gardens or enjoy the Playground, come to Harewood for a day of discovery...

The Royal Armouries is home to the United Kingdom’s national collection of arms and armour, including artillery. As a museum we have a duty of care for these objects, to keep them, study them and increase our knowledge of them, so that this can be passed to future generations along with the objects themselves.

This knowledge can be shared with others who also collect arms and armour, we are actively involved with and support a number of groups committed to the study of the subject and its practical applications. As such we offer an enquiry service to the public and the commercial world alike and have often acted as consultants on a number of film and television projects.

However, we are more than just a museum with objects in display cases, we carry out and publish research on the topic of arms and armour, carry out research on behalf of other museums. Act as specialists in the field, and we even loan out objects to other institutions.

This may sound very dull, but we also use our knowledge and collection in a fun way. We put on events for the public, jousting, military displays, and exhibitions.

This is not the only way in which we use our knowledge and collection, we do very important work in the community, working with Youth Offending Teams, on knife and gun crime prevention. As one of the largest collections of guns and knives in the world we are uniquely placed to offer a different insight into how and why people use weapons.

We also work with groups such as Flashpoint, Leap and have launched our own campaign No To Knives: NTK, these are about raising awareness and resolving or avoiding conflict.

The Leeds Grand Theatre and Opera House was built in 1878 in a backlash to the music hall tradition which was thought by ‘polite society’ to lower the tone of entertainment via the sort of humour presented in these pub-based establishments.

The theatre was built on a site of approximately three quarters of an acre with a frontage on New Briggate of 56 yards, including the Assembly Rooms.

The theatre cost a total of £62,000 and took 13 months to build. The architect, George Corson, was heavily influenced by his assistant James Robertson Watson who had undertaken a tour of Europe’s churches and theatres.

Many of the design inspirations came from these continental influences, in particular the gothic, ecclesiastical spires. The exterior is in a mixture of Romanesque and Scottish baronial styles, while the interior has such gothic motifs as fan-vaulting and clustered columns.

Only those sitting in the best seats were allowed to use the theatre's main entrance. All other patrons were ushered through side entrances in order for the class-conscious Victorians to remain separated from people below their ranks. However there was a ‘transfer staircase’ which enabled any member of the audience to better his or her position by paying more. Only the Orchestra Stalls had conventional seating.

The Dress Circle and Boxes were furnished with free standing chairs, and all other parts of the house had benches. They ranged from upholstered, in the Upper Circle, to plain wooden and back-less in the Gallery which cost a shilling admission. ‘Packers’ were employed to maximise the number of people sitting on these wooden benches making the experience all the more cramped…and hot!

The Grand Theatre celebrated the 125th anniversary of its opening in 2003. It is widely regarded as a major milestone in Victorian theatre building. The scene dock has one of the most complete Victorian scenic paint shops left in Great Britain. This is extremely rare and still in use.

The first performance at the theatre was Much Ado About Nothing on 18 November 1878 and stars that have trodden the boards over the years have included Sarah Bernhardt, Ellen Terry, Julie Andrews, Felicity Kendal, Morecambe and Wise and Laurence Olivier.

Seating 1550 at full capacity, the auditorium provides a home for performances of all types.

An enormous range of notable dance, drama, comedy and music productions have been seen at the Grand.

Since opening in March 1990, West Yorkshire Playhouse has established a reputation both nationally and internationally as one of Britain's most exciting producing theatres, winning awards for everything from its productions to its customer service.

The West Yorkshire Playhouse complex comprises: The Quarry Theatre (750 seats), The Courtyard Theatre (350 seats) a CAMRA award-winning bar, a restaurant, The Newlyn Gallery, two function rooms (The Congreve Room and The Priestley Room), three rehearsal spaces, a recording studio, extensive technical workshops, dressing rooms, a Costume Hire department and offices for production, administrative and artistic teams.

The Playhouse provides both a thriving focal point for the communities of West Yorkshire, and theatre of the highest standard for audiences throughout the region and beyond. West Yorkshire Playhouse produces 16 of its own shows each year in its two auditoria, approximately a third of which are world or British premieres. It stages over 1000 performances, workshops, readings and community events, watched by over 250,000 people, while countless others use the building as a meeting place for business and pleasure.

Funding for the Playhouse comes from Arts Council England (£1,100,000), Leeds City Council (£820,000), Leeds Education Authority (£84,000) and West Yorkshire Grants (£97,000). The Playhouse has over twenty-five corporate members in its Directors' Club including Evans property group, Carlsberg Tetley, Yorkshire Post, ITV Yorkshire and Leeds Metropolitan University.

First Floor is West Yorkshire Playhouse’s place where young people between the ages of 11 (at Secondary School) and 19 can take part in creative activites.

Young people’s or arts organisations can hire space at First Floor, subject to availability. Spaces which can be hired are:

Spacious Performing Arts Studio (approx 150m2), which can be divided into two smaller studios by soundproof, white board partitioning. (NB This studio is not suitable for dance). Sub-divided Studios can be hired separately.

Visual Arts Studio (approx 44m2), which has lots of natural light and has its own sink and sump.

Other facilities include Green Room; Kitchenette with microwave, fridge and hot water dispenser; WC and changing facilities, including ‘silver standard’ accessible toilet with hoist.

Access to First Floor is via buzzer entry system at street level. Accompanied lift access available.

First Floor is right in the city centre and forms part of 6 St Peter’s Building, which is next to Yorkshire Dance, opposite the BBC building and just across the road from the Bus Station.

Established in 2009, we have welcomed dancers from all over Europe for workshops, castings, rehearsals, classes and more! Our diverse range of activities cater for all ages and abilities and we are continually striving to deliver the best possible service for our customers

The Dance Studio Leeds is based in a converted textile mill very close to Leeds city centre.

Since its establishment the studio has welcomed clients from all aspects of the arts and beyond to the studio, including the likes of the BBC, West End Theatre companies, and some of the largest dance organisations in the UK, who have used the space for their regional castings, rehearsals and classes.

We always endeavour to work with the community and local projects by actively supporting: Young Enterprise; NSPCC; Leeds Fashion Show; Leeds Rocks; Freshly Brewed; LUU Modern Dance Society, and various other individual dance artists and companies. We wish to continue to do so in order to help Leeds develop as a vibrant and cultural city, in particular increasing the services and opportunities for dancers in our region.
At Rock School you receive personal and group tuition with qualified professional tutors. Improve your playing and learn the tricks to write a killer song!

In the traditional Farm buildings there are regular craft demonstrations such as butter-making and blacksmithing as well as children’s craft and story-telling clubs.

Admission costs – a LeedsCard discount applies. Family tickets available.

Opening hours

Summer March - October (times change with the clocks)

How to get there

By Car: 4 miles from Leeds City Centre B6159 or 2 miles from M1 J46
By bus: On Sunday a direct bus 63a during the week . 18 or 18a to Whitkirk and one mile level walk.
Dance studio centre in Mabgate Mills close to Leeds City Centre with free parking on weekends and evenings.
Northern School of Contemporary Dance is a unique dance training institution offering a select group of students the opportunity to develop and excel as dance artists in a conservatoire environment.

The space is 470 acres including ancient woodland which is a haven for wildlife. The friends of Middleton Park provide a programme of events including outdoor theatre, history and wildlife walks and children's games and history.

Choose from a great selection of books from within our landmark building. We have fabulous fiction and information titles, including in-depth art, music, business, family and local history, European information services and more.  Book a computer FREE for internet browsing or to use our range of online resources, such as ancestry.com and UKnewsstand. Our regular events range from monthly readers’ groups to creative writers groups, storytimes to inventors’ group, work club to craft group, enterprise club and beyond.

The Stanley & Audrey Burton Theatre is Leeds' newest theatre, located on Quarry Hill, next to BBC Yorkshire, West Yorkshire Playhouse and Leeds College of Music. The theatre is inside the stunning home of Northern Ballet and Phoenix Dance Theatre, but our programme is not all dance. We offer live music, theatre and comedy. Of course you can see dance too – there’s regular performances from Northern Ballet and Phoenix Dance Theatre, alongside a host of other dance artists.

Left Bank Leeds is the award-winning venue growing out of the near-ruin of a neo-gothic cathedral hidden in plain sight in Hyde Park. We are a multipurpose arts venue but also available for private hire.

The Wild Pansy Press Project Space offers a public venue for experimental works which use the practices of reading, writing and publication as their medium and/or content and will be open to the public during the week. It is sited in the School of Fine Art, History of Art & Cultural Studies of the University Of Leeds.

item.place_title: School of Fine Art, School of Music and the Brotherton Library

item.description: Leeds Gallery is an independent commercial art gallery in Leeds, West Yorkshire specialising in Photography, Illustration and Fine Art. With a focus that is both local and national the gallery’s aim is to support local arts and culture while also bringing artists and their work to the city from further afield.
Seven is an arts space with a difference. It is an independent arts venue in Chapel Allerton, Leeds 7, with events most evenings and a cafe/bar serving great food; open from 10.30am every day.

item.place_title: To be revealed as part of the Sneaky Experience

item.description: Formed in early 2011 BasementArtsProject was set up to provide a permanent arts venue for Leeds. We have an all year round programme of events and exhibitions that range across the arts from Painting through to film and performance. If you would like details of how to find us and join our mailing list for invites please contact Bruce at basementartsproject@gmail.com.

The New Headingley Club is a small private club standing in our own expansive grounds with private parking located on St. Michael's Road in Headingley. The atmosphere is quiet and friendly  with a comfortable lounge where you can simply enjoy a daily newspaper, a quiet chat and drink at reasonable prices.
A vibrant and welcoming space for a wide range of people to meet, mix, work and play.

The Howard Assembly Room is a captivating, inspiring performance venue in the centre of Leeds. This beautifully restored venue is loved for its rich and varied programme of music, film, words and performance, and has welcomed world-class musicians, performers and writers including Brad Mehldau, The Unthanks, Dhafer Youssef, The Tallis Scholars and Joanna MacGregor.

The 300 capacity venue is curated by the award-winning national opera company, Opera North. The company's fresh and vibrant approach to the art form is reflected in the range of gigs, film screenings, talks, workshops and installations that are presented in the Howard Assembly Room. For a full list of events please visit our website.

Leeds Corn Exchange is one of Britain’s finest Victorian buildings and a Grade 1 listed structure. Designed by Cuthbert Brodrick and completed in 1864, Leeds Corn Exchange holds tremendous significance both as an architectural masterpiece and cultural icon. Now just one of three Corn Exchanges in the country which still operates in its traditional capacity as a centre for trade, Leeds Corn Exchange sits at the heart of the local community.

Built in 1865, this much loved venue, hidden in the heart of Leeds city centre, has survived virtually unchanged across three centuries while most other Victorian Music Halls have passed into history. Many of the world's greatest entertainers have trodden the boards here including, Charlie Chaplin, Buster Keaton, Harry Houdini, Lilly Langtry, Harry Lauder and Mickey Rooney. It has played a key role in the careers of the likes of Frankie Vaughan, Ken Dodd, Ray Alan (and Lord Charles!), The Chuckle Brothers, Roy Hudd and Barry Cryer. For thirty years, the Varieties was also the home of BBC TV's record breaking The Good Old Days which began broadcasting in 1953 and was screened around the world.

Old Broadcasting House, Leeds Metropolitan University, home of  nti Leeds's  innovative coworking space and specialist digital training  facilities.  The coworking space first opened in Autumn 2007 and is now home to a
community of startups, and independent, freelancers.

Leeds’ legendary  music venue has been well and truly rockin’ for the last 17 years! Characterised by its distinctive curved ceilings (having been built underneath a series of three railway arches), the venue has seen notorious performances from the likes of Amy Winehouse, Queens of the Stone Age, Fall Out Boy and Mumford&Sons. Gigs take place on the three stages most nights of the week  showcasing both up and coming regional bands to national/international touring artists. Club night follow the live music on Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays where you’ll hear the best of Indie, Rock, Electro, Metal, PopPunk, Dubstep, Hip Hop and much more!

Breakfast pastries, toast, crumpets, muesli, fresh fruit salads, proper coffee, chai, fresh fruit juices, large selection of fairtrade speciality teas, sandwiches, home made soups, wholesome salads, traditional high teas, marvellous home made cakes and retro desserts.

Retro sweet shop and board games.

Available for private hire.

The White Cloth Gallery is a unique photography + film gallery with events space and café bar in the heart of the inspiring cultural city of Leeds. WCG showcases challenging, stimulating and energetic work from established and emerging artists from across the world.The first of its kind in the North of England, the White Cloth Gallery is the brainchild of creative directors Peter Dench and Sharon Price. The Leeds based events space has a unique vision to support the artistic community, encourage creativity and work alongside other local arts organisations to aid the city’s burgeoning development as a cultural centre and become a go-to destination for art lovers everywhere. Endorsing and raising funds for a number of cancer, children’s and local community charities, a percentage of the gallery’s sales and events income are donated to its elected charities.The gallery hosts regular events including workshops, seminars, screenings and book signings giving visitors the chance to meet those who exhibit.
Interplay are an arts organisation based in Leeds working in theatre, film, music and digital arts.

About

Purveyors of fine lifestyle paraphernalia. Two floor creative outlet/workshops/studios/ eventspace. Petit Bistro & Take out service. Lighting & Prop hire.
 
Description
Purveyors of:
Design classics & collectables/Vintage finds/Upcycled wares/Home decor/Urban & fine art/Apple gadgets/Post-War & Contemporary furniture/Classic & retro apparel/Bespoke tailoring/Eclectic accessories & curios/Holistic Products/Comical Oddities...
Local Delivery Available
 
General information
A hidden gem with a relaxed Sunday vibe everyday where you can enjoy design classics mixed with a hint of quirky British eccentricity.

A place to graze/socialise/peruse/purchase/relax in the surroundings of an open plan creative outlet with studios and events space.
Art Gallery . Café . Shop . Events . Promotions . Rehearsal Space . Design Studios . Creative Offices . Conference & Exhibition Space .
The Palace Picture House is a charming 24 seater cinema based within Armley Mills, Leeds Industrial Museum.

Otley Courthouse is a unique arts and resource centre, created and run by local people, in Otley, West Yorkshire.

Open Monday to Saturday 10am to 4pm – plus events and room hires.

Over the last 160 years, Leeds College of Art has contributed significantly to the development of art education in Britain, having pioneered new ways to teach and to structure qualifications. Students enjoy using our on-site art and design library as well as our spacious studios and workspaces, and our wide range of industry-standard equipment.

Hunger Hills Wood is a mature deciduous woodland belt, increasing its tree area by natural regeneration into formally open land to the west of the site.

To the north and the east are open fields, to the west a school and its grounds. The southern edge is bounded by housing.

Situated near the summit of a south facing slope, this woodland can be seen for many miles across the city and is a major contributor to the green landscape of the Aire Valley.

The woodland is used for informal recreation by a large number of the public and encloses a small stream.
, Leeds, West Yorkshire LS1 4AD
A relaxed charming city pub with a warm and friendly atmospere.

item.place_title: The Canal at Newlay (opposite Abbey Inn)

item.description: Live Art Bistro (LAB) is a new artist run venue with no fixed abode. Built on the premise that the best ideas are forever unfinished, providing artists with the space to create and the time to fail in all its potential splendour. Currently residing in a 10,000 sq. ft. New York loft style building in Leeds city centre, hosting an on-going programme of unique events centred around the Live & Performing Arts. Their aim is to create a dedicated space that bridges the gaps between the club, gallery and theatre.

Duke Studios is a  brand new Creative Space in Leeds City Centre with a huge network of creative doers, thinkers and dreamers. Our facilities include studio spaces, co-working, desk rental, meeting room and creative services such as laser cutting, photography studio and aw orkshop… Watch this space for a whole plethora of creative courses coming in 2013.
Pay-As-You-Go Industrial Workshop, Creative Courses and Business Support.

item.place_title: The Craft Centre and Design Gallery

item.description: The Tetley is a new centre for contemporary art and learning that opens 29 November 2013. Located in the stunning art deco headquarters of the former Tetley Brewery in Leeds, we’ll offer a warm welcome whether you’re coming to see cutting edge art, sample our Yorkshire menu or enjoy a pint of Tetley’s in this historic setting. We look forward to seeing you!
